title: [Untitled]
project.name: New Project
dc:title: Smart Streetlights
dc:rightsHolder.dc:name: student
dc:description.1.text: The ‘Smart Data and Lighting Network’ project aims to install intelligent control modules into existing street lights to improve how roads are used and managed. The new control modules house a suite of integrated sensors that monitor the road and dim the lights whenever the road is not in use, using a method called adaptive lighting. Detected cars or pedestrians will cause the lights to operate normally, supplying light only when it is needed, which greatly reduces the power consumption and running costs of our roads without sacrificing safety. The focus of this research is an economic analysis into adaptive street lighting, and the economic feasibility of retrofitting the system onto existing lighting installations. New and inexpensive technology, such as wireless sensor networks, has made the possibility of an intelligent lighting system closer than ever before, but the economic performance of a system using modern technology is still unknown. Each module can also monitor the external environment to provide a highly detailed and up-to-date map of the city climate. With a module in every street light, the recorded data provides a rich platform for further research in several fields, including walkability studies, urban planning, and applications in building management systems.
